case_name: Appellant (elected MLA from Laundi Constituency, Vindhya Pradesh) v. Respondent

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave against the decision of the Election Tribunal, Nowgong

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the decision of the Election Tribunal, Nowgong,

facts.text: Election Tribunal, Nowgong, set aside the election of the appellant to the Legislative Assembly, Vindhya Pradesh, from Laundi Constituency

anchor.surface_text: setting aside the election of the appellant to the Legislative Assembly, Vindhya Pradesh, from Laundi Constituency,

facts.text: Appellant employed Government servants as polling agents

anchor.surface_text: he had employed Government servants as polling agents,

facts.text: Employment of Government servants as polling agents constituted a major corrupt practice under Section 123(8) of Act 43 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: and thereby committed a major corrupt practice under Section 123 8  of Act 43 of 1951,

facts.text: There were contracts subsisting between the appellant and the Vindhya Pradesh Government for printing electoral rolls at the material period

anchor.surface_text: and secondly, that there were at the material period, contracts subsisting between the appellant and the Vindhya Pradesh Government for printing electoral rolls,

facts.text: Appellant was disqualified under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951 due to the contracts

anchor.surface_text: and that he was therefore, disqualified under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951.

facts.text: Evidence of P.W. 5 shows that the polling agent did canvassing work for the appellant

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee for the respondent referred us to the evidence of P. W. 5 which, if accepted, would show that the polling agent did also canvassing work for the appellant.

facts.text: Tribunal made no finding on whether polling agent did canvassing work

anchor.surface_text: But there is no finding of the Tribunal on this aspect of the matter,

facts.text: Tribunal's decision rests merely on the appointment by the appellant of Government servants as polling agents

anchor.surface_text: and its decision rests merely on the appointment by the appellant of Government servants as polling agents.

facts.text: There has been no contravention of Section 123(8) by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: we hold that there has been no contravention of Section 123 8  by the appellant.

facts.text: Contracts with the Chief Commissioner in Part C States operate as a disqualification under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951 read with Section 7(d) of Act 43 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the second question, we have held in the decisions already referred to, that contracts with the Chief Commissioner in Part C States would operate as a disqualification for election to the State Legislatures under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951 read along with Section 7 d  of Act 43 of 1951.

facts.text: Appellant argues that the contract for printing electoral rolls was entered into with the Election Commission not with State or Union Government

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Veda Vyas for the appellant argues that the contract for the printing of electoral rolls must be held to have been entered in to with the Election Commission and no with the State Government or the Union Government,

facts.text: Appellant relies on Article 324 of the Constitution for the argument

anchor.surface_text: and in support of this contention, relies on Article 324 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Tribunal finding that it was the Vindhya Pradesh Government that got the electoral rolls printed

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the Tribunal is that it was the Vindhya Pradesh Government that got the electoral rolls printed.

facts.text: Exhibit A-4 is a copy of a letter sent by the appellant to the Secretary to the Chief Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit A-4 is a copy of a letter sent by the appellant to the Secretary to the Chief Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh,

anchor.surface_text: and that clearly shows that it was the Vindhya Pradesh Government that settled the terms of the contract and made payments thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the second question, we have held in the decisions already referred to, that contracts with the Chief Commissioner in Part C States would operate as a disqualification for election to the State Legislatures under Section 17 of Act 49 of 1951 read along with Section 7 d  of Act 43 of 1951.

arguments.claim: Contract for printing electoral rolls entered with Election Commission not State or Union Government per Article 324

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Veda Vyas for the appellant argues that the contract for the printing of electoral rolls must be held to have been entered in to with the Election Commission and number with the State Government or the Union Government, and in support of this companytention, relies on Article 324 of the Constitution, which provides that the superintendence, direction and companytrol of the preparation of the electoral rolls shall be vested in the Election Commission, and that the President or the Governor or the Rajpramukh of a State shall, when so requested by the Election Commission, make available to the Election Commission such staff as may be necessary for the discharge of the functions

court_response_anchor.surface_text: available to the Election Commission such staff as may be necessary for the discharge of the functions companyferred on the Election Commission. Apar

arguments.court_reasoning: Preparation of electoral rolls not same as printing; Article 324 does not imply Election Commission enters printing contracts

arguments.claim: Preparation of electoral rolls distinct from printing thereof; Article 324 does not require Election Commission to enter printing contracts

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that preparation of electoral rolls is number the same thing as printing thereof, it does number follow from these provisions that the Election Commission has itself to enter into companytracts for the printing of electoral rolls.
